# Inner core

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For the cores of other planetary bodies, see [Planetary
core](/wiki/Planetary_core "Planetary core").

For a broader coverage related to this topic, see [Earth
core](/wiki/Earth_core "Earth core").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Earth_poster.svg/310px-
Earth_poster.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Earth_poster.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Earth_poster.svg "Enlarge")

The internal structure of Earth

The [Earth's](/wiki/Earth "Earth") **inner core** is the Earth's innermost
part. It is primarily a [solid](/wiki/Solid "Solid")
[ball](/wiki/Ball_\(mathematics\) "Ball \(mathematics\)") with a
[radius](/wiki/Radius "Radius") of about 1,220 kilometres (760 miles), which
is about 70% of the [Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon")'s radius.[1][2] It is composed
of an [iron–nickel alloy](/wiki/Iron%E2%80%93nickel_alloy "Iron–nickel alloy")
and some light elements. The temperature at the inner core boundary is
approximately 5700 [K](/wiki/Kelvin "Kelvin") (5400 °C).[3]

## Discovery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inner_core&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Discovery")]

The Earth was discovered to have a solid inner core distinct from its liquid
[outer core](/wiki/Outer_core "Outer core") in 1936, by the Danish
seismologist [Inge Lehmann](/wiki/Inge_Lehmann "Inge Lehmann"),[4] who deduced
its presence by studying seismograms from earthquakes in New Zealand. She
observed that the [seismic waves](/wiki/Seismic_wave "Seismic wave") reflect
off the boundary of the inner core and can be detected by sensitive
[seismographs](/wiki/Seismographs "Seismographs") on the Earth's surface. This
boundary is known as the [Bullen](/wiki/Keith_Edward_Bullen "Keith Edward
Bullen") discontinuity,[5] or sometimes as the Lehmann discontinuity.[6] A few
years later, in 1940, it was hypothesized that this inner core was made of
solid iron; its rigidity was confirmed in 1971.[7]

The [outer core](/wiki/Outer_core "Outer core") was determined to be liquid
from observations showing that [compressional waves](/wiki/Compressional_wave
"Compressional wave") pass through it, but elastic [shear](/wiki/Simple_shear
"Simple shear") waves do not – or do so only very weakly.[8] The solidity of
the inner core had been difficult to establish because the elastic [shear
waves](/wiki/Shear_wave "Shear wave") that are expected to pass through a
solid mass are very weak and difficult for seismographs on the Earth's surface
to detect, since they become so attenuated on their way from the inner core to
the surface by their passage through the liquid outer core. Dziewonski and
Gilbert established that measurements of [normal modes of
vibration](/wiki/Normal_modes "Normal modes") of Earth caused by large
earthquakes were consistent with a liquid outer core.[9] It has recently been
claimed that shear waves have been detected passing through the inner core;
these claims were initially controversial, but are now gaining acceptance.[10]

## Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inner_core&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Composition")]

Based on the relative prevalence of various chemical elements in the [Solar
System](/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System"), the theory of [planetary
formation](/wiki/Formation_and_evolution_of_the_Solar_System#Terrestrial_planets
"Formation and evolution of the Solar System"), and constraints imposed or
implied by the chemistry of the rest of the Earth's volume, the inner core is
believed to consist primarily of a [nickel-iron
alloy](/wiki/Iron%E2%80%93nickel_alloy "Iron–nickel alloy"). Pure iron was
found to be denser than the core by approximately 3%, implying the presence of
light elements in the core (e.g. silicon, oxygen, sulfur) in addition to the
probable presence of nickel.[11]

Further, if the [primordial](/wiki/History_of_Earth "History of Earth") and
mostly _[fluid](/wiki/Fluid "Fluid")_ ([still
forming](/wiki/Protoplanetary_disk "Protoplanetary disk")) earth contained any
significant mass(es) of elements denser than iron and nickel, namely the
[white](/wiki/White_metal "White metal") (appearance) [precious
metals](/wiki/Precious_metals "Precious metals") (and a few others) except
silver, specifically the [siderophile elements](/wiki/Siderophile_element
"Siderophile element") then these would necessarily have differentiated to the
very center of the core into concentric nested spheres by [Planetary
differentiation](/wiki/Planetary_differentiation "Planetary differentiation").
The most dense (and [stable](/wiki/Stable_nuclide "Stable nuclide"), i.e.
[platinum](/wiki/Platinum "Platinum"), [iridium](/wiki/Iridium "Iridium"), and
[osmium](/wiki/Osmium "Osmium"), (etc.) in order of density) of these forming
the innermost spheroid(s).[12] While _unstable_ elements of such trans-
iron/nickel density would have mostly [decayed](/wiki/Radioactive_decay
"Radioactive decay") to iron/nickel/lead by the time the earth formed a
discrete core.

See also: [Densities of the elements (data
page)](/wiki/Densities_of_the_elements_\(data_page\) "Densities of the
elements \(data page\)")

It then necessarily follows that all, or almost all, of these denser elements
we have mined (or are even able to) at the surface (or near surface, or even
at all "above" the core) have been delivered later as part of [impact
objects/masses](/wiki/Impact_event "Impact event").[13]

## Temperature and
pressure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inner_core&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Temperature and pressure")]

The temperature of the inner core can be estimated by considering both the
theoretical and the experimentally demonstrated constraints on the melting
temperature of impure iron at the pressure which iron is under at the boundary
of the inner core (about 330 [GPa](/wiki/GPa "GPa")). These considerations
suggest that its temperature is about 5,700 K (5,400 °C; 9,800 °F).[3] The
pressure in the Earth's inner core is slightly higher than it is at the
boundary between the outer and inner cores: it ranges from about 330 to 360
gigapascals (3,300,000 to 3,600,000 atm).[14] Iron can be solid at such high
temperatures only because its melting temperature increases dramatically at
pressures of that magnitude (see the [Clausius–Clapeyron
relation](/wiki/Clausius%E2%80%93Clapeyron_relation "Clausius–Clapeyron
relation")).[15]

A report published in the journal _Science_ [16] concludes that the melting
temperature of iron at the inner core boundary is 6230 ± 500 K, roughly 1000 K
higher than previous estimates.

## Dynamics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inner_core&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Dynamics")]

The Earth's inner core is thought to be slowly growing as the liquid [outer
core](/wiki/Outer_core "Outer core") at the boundary with the inner core cools
and solidifies due to the gradual cooling of the Earth's interior (about 100
degrees Celsius per billion years).[17] Many scientists had initially expected
that the inner core would be found to be
[homogeneous](/wiki/Homogeneous_mixture "Homogeneous mixture"), because the
solid inner core was originally formed by a gradual cooling of molten
material, and continues to grow as a result of that same process. Even though
it is growing into liquid, it is solid, due to the very high pressure that
keeps it compacted together even if the temperature is extremely high. It was
even suggested that Earth's inner core might be a [single
crystal](/wiki/Single_crystal "Single crystal") of iron.[18] However, this
prediction was disproved by observations indicating that in fact there is a
degree of disorder within the inner core.[19] Seismologists have found that
the inner core is not completely uniform, but instead contains large-scale
structures such that seismic waves pass more rapidly through some parts of the
inner core than through others.[20] In addition, the properties of the inner
core's surface vary from place to place across distances as small as 1 km.
This variation is surprising, since lateral temperature variations along the
inner-core boundary are known to be extremely small (this conclusion is
confidently constrained by [magnetic field](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic
field") observations). Recent discoveries suggest that the solid inner core
itself is composed of layers, separated by a transition zone about 250 to 400
km thick.[21] If the inner core grows by small frozen sediments falling onto
its surface, then some liquid can also be trapped in the pore spaces and some
of this residual fluid may still persist to some small degree in much of its
interior.

Because the inner core is not rigidly connected to the Earth's solid
[mantle](/wiki/Mantle_\(geology\) "Mantle \(geology\)"), the possibility that
it [rotates](/wiki/Rotation "Rotation") slightly faster or slower than the
rest of Earth has long been entertained.[22][23] In the 1990s, seismologists
made various claims about detecting this kind of super-rotation by observing
changes in the characteristics of [seismic waves](/wiki/Seismic_waves "Seismic
waves") passing through the inner core over several decades, using the
aforementioned property that it transmits waves faster in some directions.
Estimates of this super-rotation are around one degree of extra rotation per
year.

Growth of the inner core is thought to play an important role in the
generation of [Earth's magnetic field](/wiki/Earth%27s_magnetic_field "Earth's
magnetic field") by [dynamo](/wiki/Dynamo_theory "Dynamo theory") action in
the liquid outer core. This occurs mostly because it cannot dissolve the same
amount of light elements as the outer core and therefore freezing at the inner
core boundary produces a residual liquid that contains more light elements
than the overlying liquid. This causes it to become [buoyant](/wiki/Buoyant
"Buoyant") and helps drive convection of the outer core.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
existence of the inner core also changes the dynamic motions of liquid in the
outer core as it grows and may help fix the magnetic field since it is
expected to be a great deal more resistant to flow than the outer core liquid
(which is expected to be turbulent).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Speculation also continues that the inner core might have exhibited a variety
of internal [deformation](/wiki/Deformation_\(engineering\) "Deformation
\(engineering\)") patterns. This may be necessary to explain why seismic waves
pass more rapidly in some directions than in others.[24] Because [thermal
convection](/wiki/Thermal_convection "Thermal convection") alone appears to be
improbable,[25] any buoyant convection motions will have to be driven by
variations in composition or abundance of liquid in its interior. S. Yoshida
and colleagues proposed a novel mechanism whereby deformation of the inner
core can be caused by a higher rate of freezing at the equator than at polar
latitudes,[26] and S. Karato proposed that changes in the magnetic field might
also deform the inner core slowly over time.[27]

There is an East–West asymmetry in the inner core seismological data. There is
a model which explains this by differences at the surface of the inner core –
melting in one hemisphere and crystallization in the other.[28] The western
hemisphere of the inner core may be crystallizing, whereas the eastern
hemisphere may be melting. This may lead to enhanced magnetic field generation
in the crystallizing hemisphere, creating the asymmetry in the Earth's
magnetic field.[29]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Inner_core&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of the Earth](/wiki/History_of_the_Earth "History of
the Earth")

Based on rates of cooling of the core, it is estimated that the current solid
inner core started solidifying approximately 0.5 to 2 billion years ago[30]
out of a fully molten core (which formed just after [planetary
formation](/wiki/Planetary_core "Planetary core")). If true, this would mean
that the Earth's solid inner core is not a primordial feature that was present
during the planet's formation, but a feature younger than the Earth (the Earth
is about 4.5 billion years old).
